values:
Dang! I haven't been on this thing in awhile. I started seriously training for a marathon about two days ago (after my lame self kept putting it off forever), specifically the OBX marathon in 2010.  So I kept a running journal to keep me motivated, and found this thing again.  It might help me keep the running journal on cue, and this one as well. What's the scoop?  I'm no longer a paramedic student. I've embraced chemistry, and well I have got homework this weekend. I'm pretty much the same person, except I'll be married for about a year coming up on April 11th, 2010 to the most wonderful, beautiful, extravagant person I know, my wife.  I'm still very much interested in medicine and trying to climb that ladder, but in the specifics of being a D.O., rather than an M.D.. This economy still sucks, but I'm maintaining. Oh and I still love to surf, just when I can get some mileage to go do it. I still want to be able to use that as a mantle when I get to the top of my ladder (goals). What else? Nothing really, but hopefully I'll have some cooler crap to write about later. I'm off and running!

Sim

Ugh!


My brain's 02 capacity is so low right now.

It's been back to back tests, and I've been studying way too much, but never enough, you know?

Yesterday was this monstrosity of a pharmacology exam, today is a monstrosity of a pharmacology quiz.

But I'm not complaining. This is what I signed up for, and I am learning alot.

I'm actually giddy about the day I put this knowledge of prehospital medicine into practice.

Not alot of people know but when I was working as a medical tech in Denver at the local hospital in 2004, 

I 

would keep weird hours just to make the shift, but had this weird fascination. I'll provide details, but 

like a senile old man on his front porch with his trusty dog let me spin it in a yarn of reminiscence: 

"Back in the day"...  I averaged an 8 hour q day shift for four on/3 off, 

working on a med/surg unit. Just the simple fact that I worked at a major trauma center stoked the 

hell out of me. My commute consisted of  waking up at 5 am in the morning chasing time to make the morning

bus commute to downtown Denver.  I would then bike at least 5 miles to catch a second bus, or if I 

could sneak my bike on a lightrail to downtown, and bike at least another 2 to the hospital. Dawn wasn't

approaching until 7 am or so, so I would nap on the bus periodically. I would then park my bike

in a parking deck with a bike cage, with (as ridiculous as it sounds) my bike shoes still on my feet. I did all of my 

rounds in clipless pedal shoes, and never did my feet hurt, everyready with scrubs, stethoscope and everything 

else (pen, paper, cup of joe).

I would attend the morning briefing (always followed by a debriefing a the end of the shits) with my patient load 

with the nurses, get my side of a two tiered

hallway, at most we could hold 15 patients in a room and double occupancy if necessary. And at times with out a 

specific side , I would  be designated a sitter: one who literally sits with a pt. for the entire

shift and is usually on special medical or interventional consideration due to whatever was going

on with them (those days are burned into my memory forever, very, very, unsual, interesting circumstances

).  I would get vitals  twice q day (Blood Pressure, weight at times when ordered, temperature, respirtations, 

quick across the room assessments), CNA duties mainly, but a little more...  like check ultrasonically

levels of urine in a pt's bladder, print off ECG strips, utilize a pyxis system (a hospitals computer

accountability system for keeping tabs on drugs/supplies (but I wasn't involved with the drugs (strictly

nurses of course)), balloon catheters, really, really simple stuff (but a little more than a CNA

was qualified for).  Anyway it was the quickest job I could find with my EMT license, and I was hungry

for some type of medical experience, but always with a eye of going back home and continuing my course

work (when I found about WCU).  And  I would always watch for the MD's both residents, and attending, 

engage in procedure, at least more than once a week, maybe sometimes the same procedure.  I was always

observing them, purposefully when I had downtime. If they needed a towel, or wanted me to get extra glove

s, what could seem like stupid shit to some people I would be there when I could. I wanted to. That

is a good indication of where my fascination would lie. You see, since I worked in this unit and wore

scurbs and had my stethoscope around my neck and walked among doctors at a teaching hospital I felt 

to some extent a very close connection, even though I wasn't a medical student, or a doctor.  Although

at times and more than once family would come and visit, and if I was lucky someone from another de-

partment of the hospital would ask me, are you the doctor? Especially if I was the only one in the room

attending to the patient, with a nurse, or what have you and answer with a smile, "No, not yet."  Not to 

say that I wanted to practice medicine without a liscense or anything, which I never did, or even tried

to, but because I was in that environment I felt very strong sense of belonging. I was good with patients

even when they seemed angry or upset with me. I always strived to make them feel a little more comforta-

able in a place out of their norm (and more often than not, their only norm). And I got good feedback, 

from my bosses, the nurses.  Even though it lasted 4 months, as soon as I had the money saved up for a

plane ticket I left for NC again, it was pretty damn intense. Not only did I had to reverse my bikeride

in the dark, and wait another hour for the bus at times (sometimes in the snow, and freezing ass rain)

I worked fall to early winter there, I loved every tiring, aching minute of it.  I remember some pts. 

over others, but never kept a journal, regrettably. I can't recall every day, 

but the feeling of being there will never leave me.  That might seem like a dumb fascination, or 

a little skewed but it'll play into my future for real. One of the most emotional times for me

was working in the ICU, and seeing so much effort into keeping someone alive, mostly by machine, and

constant, vigilant monitoring. I'm sure I got as much of a cardiovascular workout as biking to the 

hospital running to tell the nurses/doctors about respirator alarms going off or loose IV's.  I even

took a ECG class for nurses, there. Fact: Paramedics know more about ECG's than nurses ever will. Not to 

seem like an elitist, or anything, but even though that class blew my mind then, now I understand them 

pretty damn good (but not as a totality), not at least until the end of the semester or when clinical's 

come up next semester, and I'm interpreting them via real time. But whatever, it might play a role in

my future. Denver Health has a pediatrics program for physician's assistants. I don't like to weigh

to much on the future, without living my present time into the fullest extent possible, and preparing 

for the kind of future I want, but I could very well see myself in those same halls (or hospital)  7 to 10 years from 

now.

"Excuse me sir, are you the doctor?" "Well no, but I am a PA (or I could try for an MD, who the hell 

knows?) How may I assist you today?"

Yeah, it's what I signed up for. And I'm tired. It's only going to get harder, and I am only 

going to get way more tired.

Bring it on.

Well,

  Just studying my ass off. 

Learning like 9 different drugs to give to pts. a week, end of the semester it should total around 

110 drugs or so.  My school job here, I've been totally blowing it off with the amount of studying 

I've been doing, it's taking precedence over everything else.  Every now and then on a nice day, 

I'll take in the sunrise over the mountains and enjoy my surroundings. One weird detail at a coffee shop,

since I practically live in the library on the weekday nights, I stopped by for some cappuchino. There

were about 7 people in there, including the baristas (sp?) and were carrying on like two different con-

versations. I wasn't really listnening, but just kind of phased out and time sort of slowed down. No,

I'm not on drugs or anything, it just seemed like a peaceful moment, kind of like some meditative moments

I've had before, but I'm trying to meditate. As it passed I ended up getting an extra cup of this 

cappuchino/ice cream mix because they made too much. Maybe I did have a moment in the universe there, 

what the hell, I got extra coffee, score!  Last weekend for the 2nd time I went skydiving (tandem).  

I did it a couple of years ago when I was living in Denver, and well there was this big party of people 

(who run the jump school), people walking around with Wild Turkey and shit, and some of the people 

on this school sponsered trip were underage. Two of those students decided to imbibe, and well let's just

say I played EMT that night, and I do so say myself quite well (with puke and everything!) The next day

we jumped after retiring our campsite. The only noticeable difference with this jump compared to my first

one was that I wasn't throwing any strange heart rates of excitement, I was just kind of chilled to 

the whole episode, and that aside from a straight jump our plane opened from the back, so you could flip

do a gainer, backflip, whatever the hell you wanted. My jumpmaster, Liam, asked me "do you want to 

backflip or do a gainer?" "What's better?" "A gainer!" Next thing I know my orientation was off the map, 

as flipped every which way. Another thing to mention is when it was my turn to help turn the chute

Liam made it extra fast, and I believe threw in an extra spin.  We slid into our dropzone after jumping

14,000 feet. Someday I'm going to take a class, and suggest to everyone that can should experience

skydiving.  How much more closer to flying can you get? Not much, for damn sure.

Other than that piece of news, I'm working on my studies as of now. Which I should probably get back 

to....

Later,

Sim

Okay, this weekend was supposed to be pretty much routine: I wake up, go to church,  hang out with my dad's side of the 

family (in Western NC) and go to my hole in the wall and study for class tomorrow.

Turns out a tad bit different.  Around 3 am I went biking again (on my same route 3  miles down a mountain, 3 miles back 

up). 

On the way over a bridge of the river Kwai (actually the Tuckeseegee) this white four legged thing with fangs jumps out 

in front of my bike, obviously startled. I'm probably barreling at 20+ mph, and let out my best scream reminiscent of 

William Wallace, retaliating at this beast growling and running across the road. I thought it was a wolf, or a coyote it 

was too dark to be sure.  After having made it to my destination, I plunk down some change for Dannon yogurt's "Win a 

$25,000 nest egg" competition (at the super market). If I collect enough tin coverings from the yogurt containers 

contaning polysyllabic pieces of things like "Be Happy!" that's half of my P.A. school paid for. Anyway I got more 

divergence than convegence but I wolfed down five cups of yogurt scared for my life at the beast probably waiting 

to attack me, who knows, maybe they'd bring the entire pack this time.

Well, I made it safely back up the mountain to my dormitory.

And so began my morning...

So far no wolves at my door.  I awake at 9 am, and turn my car on to gas up. I haven't gassed up since I got back 

to school, but it was dead. What the hell, I thought? So I call the campus police, they jumpstart my car, and I 

buy some fossil fuel. I checked to make sure before I pumped if it would restart and it did. However to no avail

after paying for my consumption it dies again. Panicking I think about what to do after my cell phone is almost 

dead, and screaming for available service. I improvise and ask some guys in baseball uniforms in a heavy duty

pick up for some jumper cables. Nope, they don't have any. I say cool, exchange pleasantries and am about to cry 

in the middle of the station (yes, I'm in touch with my feelings) until one of the guys comes up to me with a 

jumppack and says there might be some juice left. No go. Well the beauty of owning a straight drive is I can 

engage the clutch to boost the battery in a downward momentum. They help me push it, and off I go in 1st gear.

The electron gods smile upon me a second time around and I'm off to church, or so I think.  3 Jamaican students

(upon further inquiry I find out WCU is hosting Jamaican students this summer majoring in education to receive some final 

credits towards their degree) flag me down for a ride to a church. I oblige and with my new friends who don't 

really know where the church is, tell me of a good surf spot outside of Kingston and decide to abandon their

original destination for a church close by. They tell me I'm very kind, and I make sure they have a way back 

to campus, they insist it's a church van they call a bus, will take them back. I inquire further, and they 

say they will be alright and off they go. The whole time I leave my car running just in case. Well strangely 

enough, like some bad episode of Twin Peaks I saw the beast on the side of the road. It was obviously not 

breathing, and lifeless. I maneuver and walk up to the median where the inanimate object lay. It is a medium size

dog, like an Akita, with a beautiful white coat. My wolf. I feel sorry for the guy, and even angrier for the owners
 
who probably didn't secure the dog well enough for it to not  run rampant on the highway. It looked taken care of, 

minus any means of identification. I close my eyes and say a prayer for this animal, and hop back in my car. 

I later find out there is some weird electrical thing with my car in which my taillights are constantly on

draining 6 amperes of battery power, so as a fucked up measure of saving juice I take off one of the terminals.

I decide if I get any funny looks from passerby after stopping and having to raise and close my hood after each 

cycle of turning the car on/off, I'll just tell them it's a red neck security feature. 

Other than that I missed church but felt I did more worthwhile things this morning than I would've done in my routine.

After that I finally got to met up with my relatives and ate some free food, got a haircut, and watched as my 

cousins dog chased around a metal bowl about the size of itself (it's a little terrier). It literally picked up

the bowl with it's mouth, flipped the bowl in the air and attacked it like I thought my phantom wolf would've 

attacked me but the bowl would've been thy metal frame of my bike.  And with this I  just had a random thought: I get this footage

on DVR, send it in to Animal Planet, collect some mad dough, and pay for half of the other half of PA school.  Hmmm...

Maybe with a steady diet of yogurt, and videotaping this dog I'll be closer to my goal than I can imagine.  Maybe 

today wasn't so weird after all....

I can't wait for tomorrow. 

Ciao,

Sim

Alright, back on top of things at school...


My computer is up and running again, and summer semester is underway. I'm taking 


more chemistry, really an intro to Organic and I really can't say much but that the class 


is everyday. I feel confident and ready. Come fall, I start my program and I'm even 


more stoked about that. I'm trying to be intentiontally  positive for what's upcoming, 


and  it's good. Last night, in Cullowhee, which is 45 minutes outside of Asheville, NC 


I hopped on my bike to Wally World to get some things. Unbelievable. Crazily enough 


it was 5 am in the morning, I have a penchant for staying up way late on the 


weekends, & tested out the bike. I got it for school at a wonderful store in Greensboro 


called Reicycles. They refurbish used bikes, and you can get them for cheap. It's a old


skool Specialized "Rockhopper" mountain bike, no shocks or anything.  But it's tough as 


hell, and I was enjoying the darkness, surrounded by the trees, and pumping my legs up 


hills I never knew I could conquer. This semester I'm gonna plan to bike that route alot. 


Biking in the Appalachian mountains kicks ass. Well that's about it: more later, 


when I explore more. In the meantime live fully, and don't go out looking 


like a fool.  BTW: I couldn't fully give up eating meat, I blame it on my mom's cooking! :)

It's been awhile up on this thang.

I've been mitigating studying for finals coming up, getting over food poisoning from the last break, and taking the last of my exams (before finals).

So far I've come up ahead.

I became vegetarian again (thanks to the food poisoning-but I still eat fish, and I've sworn off fast food for an indeterminable period now, at least until I don't have to drive long enough and have to satiate myself with what I find on an exit ramp.)

I made an A on my last Physics exam (which is a first, for me, since well, since... forever). I think I'm finally clicking with the stuff now. I'm stoked. Celebrated with some wine. Good times.

I'm considering working for the National Park Service for next fall (2007) in Sequoia/Kings National Park area, to save up some money for school. We'll see how that goes, I got this contact and I'm going to go through the motions over time, once I get the application. It'll be for fire prevention, digging fuel lines to counter wild blazes. Sounds dangerous, but I'm interested, and it's good pay. Plus it's California! Shit... on break, I'm headed west out there (if it's feasible).

So I'm maintaining. Sounds somewhat boorish, but I'll have something more exciting next time. Wish me luck on my exams.

Being the end of the weekend, and how I was supposed to go on this mountain climbing trip (postponed due to snow), I sort of dumbfounded my way into "hanging out" and had plenty of time on my hands.

I then cleaned my room, and found this paper, something I wrote on Valentine's day. I thought, cool this could go in my journal being that I really didn't do anything to much exciting to write about, so here goes:

"An eclipse of my spirit":

  "I just had a thought. Sitting here by myself molting a new skin made from inhaling a raisin-cucumber salad shared with a bratwurst dipped in sauerkraut sandwich, I elevate the role of staying balanced by being a step ahead of myself. When I go snowboarding in Colorado, I'll be mimicking the act of surf. Deep carves, for possibly two days in a row. Mixing it up, along with the longboard skateboarding I found myself doing today. The surfer busting out of me, for which I've kept hidden or muted unfold, I'll grow into it. Watch out! The person you rode to shore in on April of 2002 is coming back full throttle. Even though I carry myself in a loner manner, at times shy and quiet, I'm forming the mind to be in that giant hollow tube called Pipeline. Prepare for the day. It draws near. Live like water."


--Well, it turned out more of an expression of my thought processes at the time, but I liked it. However there was no snowboarding in Colorado (over this past spring break), because of a little incident but I still think at times I kind of hold  back being the "surfer" I made myself when I left California, because people seemed bored by it when I talk about it. But, I did undergo a change that year (2002), and I spent of lot of time prospecting introspection, if you will. It did change my state of mind, I feel more laid back than ever. I really think the surfing brought that out, and I haven't completeley let that go, though at times  I have struggled with my life...getting back in school, relocating, working my ass off...but it's now starting to pay off. And even though, due to finances, or just not having the time, I have surfed back home in NC. Not as often as I would have liked, but just enough to give thanks to the powers that be to let me exist in that pattern in my life.

So I think, and have thought about it. When I graduate, I want to plan the most massive surf trip on my own I can imagine. I want to travel up and down the California coast, camping, exploring all the little breaks, or maybe even beyond (outta the US perhaps?). You may be asking yourself, what the hell am I'm talking about? Simple. It's the act of riding a wave that I taught myself, and left before I was fully cultivated (getting to connect turns, just hanging out, surfing when the weather permitted)...when  I left California. Well I got some work to do, and I'm here. So once I get my professional life started, playing the sport I love the most will consume me. I want it to, if you haven't noticed already. Once a surfer, always a surfer, or at least your mind is there when the  hills and valleys of the mountains separate you from the ocean. I plan to get back as much as I can, and squeeze in as much as time surfing as time  will allow while I'm here at school.  

Just a thought I had. Or just trying to be a step ahead of myself.

March 25th, 2006... A day that will live on in infamy....whatever...

Anyway, here I am. Shout out to my friend Anne for letting me in on this thang. Ain't nothing but a chicken wang, dang. I guess I'll treat 
this like a diary of sorts. What did I do today? Nada mucha. I got a chemistry exam I'm preparing to study for, and I'm in a process of 
self discovery because I'm falling in love with chemistry, or you could probably say re-discovery, because I love the chemical nature of 
things. We are all a self aware smorgasbord of chemical influences and reactions, and I'm planningto get into the business of helping maintain people who want to live healthy lives. In other words, I'm getting into medicine, and no one is stopping me. That's why I'm in school, it's been a little break to get back in, but I'm here. What else today? Um, nothing much... went swimming. I do that alot. Being in the mountains, the surf is limited so I'm trying to maintain my physique once I move to a permanent residence somewhere in coastal California 
(oh in about 5 years or so I would say). Oh yeah, everyone should check out the podcast of the weekly radio address under the comedy folder 
in itunes. 

That shit keeps me laughing all throughout the week. 

Vaya con dios, amigos.


Simmons
